## Similarity Measure

-   Objects (or data points) that are **close together** are considered **similar**.

<!-- -->

-   If two objects are far apart, they are considered **less similar (or dissimilar)**.

<!-- -->

-    We use **similarity measures** to mathematically check how close two objects are.

<!-- -->

-    Examples:

    -   **Distance** → small distance = more similar.

    -   **Correlation** → high correlation = more similar.

### 1.EUCLIDEAN DISTANCE

![](images/clipboard-1067972216.png)

```{r}
library(stats)

P <- 1:10/sum(1:10)
Q <- 20:29/sum(20:29)

x<- rbind(P,Q)
 dist(x,method = 'euclidean')

```

![](images/clipboard-2704122268.png)

```{r}
dist(x, method = "minkowski")
```

![](images/clipboard-789436254.png)

```{r}
library(philentropy)
distance(x,method = 'jaccard')
```

![](images/clipboard-812028861.png)

**Example**

```{r}
#Data preparation 1
 Murder = c(15.4,13,9,11.3,8.1,11.4) 
 Assault = c(335,337,276,300,294,285) 
 Rape = c(31.9,16.1,40.6,27.8,31,32.1) 
 Urban = c(80,45,91,67,80,70) 
 crime = cbind(Murder, Assault, Rape, Urban) 
 row.names(crime) = c("A","B","C","D","E","F")
 
 #To get the distance matrix 9
 distance = dist(crime, method = "euclidean")
 distance
```
